questions.text: An otherwise healthy 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because she has not had a menstrual period. Examination shows normal breast development. She now reports having a headache and visual disturbances for the past 12 hours. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 164/80 mm Hg.  Urine dipstick test for protein is negative. Which of the following is the most likely primary component in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Abnormal remodelling of spiral arteries

questions.text: A 36-year-old primigravid woman at 15 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She has not been taking prenatal vitamins and admits to consuming alcohol regularly. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 15-week gestation. A quadruple screening test shows markedly elevated maternal serum a-fetoprotein. Maternal serum concentrations of ß-human chorionic gonadotropin, estriol, and inhibin A are normal. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Spina bifida cystica

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of multiple episodes of bilious vomiting. She is diagnosed with intestinal malrotation and volvulus and undergoes emergency laparotomy. During surgery, a 3 x 3 cm cystic mass is excised from behind the umbilicus. Microscopic examination of the mass shows mature nonciliated columnar epithelium with some goblet cells lining the inner cyst wall. Dilation of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's mass?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Vitelline duct

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal examination. Her previous pregnancy was uncomplicated and she gave birth to a healthy boy. Her blood group is A, Rh-negative. The father's blood group is B, Rh-positive. Administration of which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Anti-D IgG

choices.text: Continue the pregnancy as it is
Remove IUCD and terminate pregnancy

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) in place becomes pregnant. She wants to continue the pregnancy. On examination, the thread of the IUCD is visible. What should be the next course of action?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Remove the IUCD

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn presents with respiratory distress and abdominal distension. A nasogastric tube was inserted, and an X-ray was performed as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Type C TEF

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman, gravida 5 para 5, comes to the OPD due to involuntary, intermittent loss of urine over the past 5 months. The patient loses a small amount of urine when asked to cough. She has no dysuria, urgency, or hematuria and usually awakens once a night to void.  Postvoid residual urine volume is 40 mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urethral hypermobility

 

  • Diagnosis: Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) due to urethral hypermobility.
  • Seen in multiparous women with weakened pelvic floor and loss of urethral support.
  • Mechanism: The pelvic floor and endopelvic fascia normally stabilize the proximal urethra. When these supports are weakened, increased intra-abdominal pressure (cough, sneeze, laugh) transiently exceeds urethral closing pressure → leakage of urine.
  • Clinical features: Leakage only with exertion, coughing, or laughing. No urgency or nocturia. Normal postvoid residual volume

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bladder outlet obstruction: Causes hesitancy, weak stream, incomplete emptying, and high residual volume, not intermittent leakage.

 

Option B. Detrusor overactivity: Causes urge incontinence (sudden urge, cannot hold urine). Associated with frequency and nocturia, not stress triggers.

 

Option D. Vesicovaginal fistula: Causes continuous, painless leakage of urine unrelated to activity. Common after pelvic surgery or prolonged labor, not intermittent or exertion-related.

choices.text: ACTH low, Aldosterone low, Cortisol low
ACTH low, Aldosterone high, Cortisol low
ACTH high, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low
ACTH low, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low

questions.text: Two days after vaginal delivery of a healthy newborn at term, a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, is unable to breastfeed. Her labor was complicated by antepartum hemorrhage and she received two units of packed red blood cells. Her pulse is 99/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following sets of serum findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ACTH low, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low

 

This patient presents with inability to breastfeed two days postpartum, hypotension, and a history of significant antepartum hemorrhage with blood transfusions, suggesting postpartum hypopituitarism (Sheehan syndrome).

 

In Sheehan syndrome, ischemic necrosis of the pituitary leads to decreased secretion of anterior pituitary hormones, including ACTH, resulting in secondary adrenal insufficiency with low cortisol levels. Aldosterone secretion is typically preserved because it is regulated mainly by the renin-angiotensin system, not ACTH.

 

Therefore, the most likely serum findings are: ACTH low, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ACTH low, Aldosterone low, Cortisol low: Aldosterone is usually normal because it is regulated independently of ACTH.

 

Option B. ACTH low, Aldosterone high, Cortisol low: Aldosterone is unlikely to be high in this context.

 

Option C. ACTH high, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low: ACTH would be low due to pituitary failure, not high.

choices.text: Silver nitrate exposure

questions.text: A 15-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician for evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 3 days. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received  irregular prenatal care during the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Examination of the newborn shows watery discharge in both eyes and mild swelling. Which of the following is the most  likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Chlamydia trachomatis

questions.text: The World Health Organization suggests the use of a new rapid diagnostic test for the diagnosis of malaria in resource-limited settings. The new test has a sensitivity of 70% and a specificity of 90% compared to the gold standard test (blood smear). The validity of the new test is evaluated at a satellite health center by testing 200 patients with a positive blood smear and 150 patients with a negative blood smear. How many of the tested individuals are expected to have a false negative result?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 60

 

False negatives occur among those who truly have malaria (blood-smear positive) and are missed by the test. 

 

Sensitivity = 70% means the test correctly identifies 70% of true positives and misses 30%.

 

Remember the formulae:

 

Here,

 

For 200 true positives, 30% × 200 = 60 false negatives. So 60 individuals with positive blood smears will test negative on the rapid test.

questions.text: In Piaget's theory of cognitive development, the concepts of "out of sight, out of mind" and focusing on the "here and now" are characteristic of which developmental stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sensorimotor stage

 

In Piaget’s theory of cognitive development, the sensorimotor stage is the first stage, spanning from birth to about 2 years of age. During this stage, a child learns to understand the world primarily through sensory experiences and motor interactions with the environment.

 

Key Features of the Sensorimotor Stage:

 

  • "Out of sight, out of mind" → This reflects lack of object permanence, meaning the child does not understand that objects continue to exist even when they are not visible. For example, if a toy is hidden under a blanket, the child will not search for it.
  • Focus on the "here and now" → The child’s thought process is limited to immediate perceptions and actions; there is no abstract or representational thinking yet.
  • Development of object permanence marks the transition to the next stage (around 8–12 months).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Preoperational stage (2–7 years): Characterized by symbolic thinking, egocentrism, and animism. Children begin to use language and imagination but lack logical reasoning.

 

Option C. Concrete operational stage (7–11 years): Children develop logical thinking about concrete objects, understand conservation of mass, number, and volume, and can take others’ perspectives.

 

Option D. Formal operational stage (≥12 years): Involves abstract reasoning, hypothetical thinking, and systematic problem-solving.

 

Summary Table

choices.text: Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels

Generation of adenosine triphosphate

choices.text: Defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane
Deletion in the long arm of chromosome 7
Aspiration due to abnormal communication between airway and esophagus

questions.text: Sixteen hours after delivery, a newborn develops respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation with a birth weight of 3200 g. Pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. Physical examination shows tachypnea and bluish discoloration of the extremities. Auscultation of the chest shows diffuse crackles in the lung fields and a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Abdominal x-ray shows absence of bowel gas. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this newborn's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Aspiration due to abnormal communication between airway and esophagus

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Social smile – 2months
  2. Walk without support -12months
  3. Babbling gibberish-15months
  4. Walk upstairs with alternate foot – 4yrs
  5. Copy a circle-2yrs
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1, 3

choices.text: Underestimation of gestational age
Spina bifida occulta
Gestational trophoblastic disease

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 17 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal examination. Serum studies at 16 weeks' gestation showed an abnormally elevated a-fetoprotein level and normal beta human chorionic gonadotropin and estriol levels. After genetic counseling, the patient decides to continue with the pregnancy without any diagnostic testing. The remainder of her pregnancy is uncomplicated and she delivers a boy at 38 weeks' gestation. Analysis of the infant's leukocytes shows a 46, XY karyotype. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the abnormal second-trimester test results?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Underestimation of gestational age

questions.text: A 37-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of heavy, prolonged bleeding with menstruation, dyspareunia, and cyclical abdominal pain. Pelvic examination shows an asymmetrically enlarged, nodular uterus consistent in size with a 10-week gestation. A photomicrograph of a section of an endometrial biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Leiomyoma

choices.text: The cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor are Engagement →  Crowning → Flexion → Restitution → Internal rotation
cOCPS have no role in protection against HIV and STDs
Warning bleeds are a feature of placenta previa

An upper segment cesarean section is done in case of perimortem cesarean section if there is no return of spontaneous circulation in 5 minutes in a pregnant woman who has experienced total cardiopulmonary arrest

questions.text: All of the following are true except:
questions.solution: Ans. A) The cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor are Engagement →  Crowning → Flexion → Restitution → Internal rotation

choices.text: Maintenance of the corpus luteum
Inhibition of ovulation
Development of breast tissue

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of nausea and vomiting. Her last menstrual period was 9 weeks ago. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Ultrasonography shows an intrauterine pregnancy consistent in size with a 7-week gestation. The hormone that was measured in this patient's urine to detect the pregnancy is also directly responsible for which of the following processes?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Maintenance of the corpus luteum

choices.text: The fetal head is partially extended, vaginal delivery with chin posterior
The fetal head is partially extended, cesarean section
The fetal head is fully extended; assisted vaginal delivery
The fetal head is flexed, spontaneous vaginal delivery

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in labor presents with a brow presentation. What is the characteristic attitude of the fetal head in a brow presentation, and what is the most appropriate mode of delivery for this presentation?
questions.solution: Ans. B) The fetal head is partially extended, cesarean section

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented in OPD with recurrent respiratory infections and thickened sputum. Chest X-ray is shown. Patient also had steatorrhea since birth. What is the likely defect?
questions.solution: Ans. A) F508 Deletion

questions.text: 28-year women with history of an ectopic pregnancy presents with subfertility of 3 years. She complains of recurrent vaginal discharge. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals the following. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Hydrosalpinx

choices.text: Consumption of intravascular clotting factors
Rupture of the uterine wall
Defective decidual layer of the placenta

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 35 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her three children were delivered by Cesarean section. One hour after vaginal delivery, the placenta is not delivered. Manual separation of the placenta leads to profuse vaginal bleeding. Her pulse is 122/min and blood pressure is 90/67 mm Hg. A firm, nontender uterine fundus is palpated at the level of the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's postpartum bleeding?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Defective decidual layer of the placenta

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a 3-month history of vulvar itching and pain. She was diagnosed with lichen sclerosus 4 years ago. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Physical examination shows a 2.5-cm nodular, ulcerative lesion on the vaginal introitus and left labia minora with surrounding erythema. Punch biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows enlarged lymph nodes concerning for metastatic disease. Which of the following lymph node regions is the most likely primary site of metastasis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Superficial inguinal

choices.text: Superior vena cava

questions.text: An investigator is studying the relationship between fetal blood oxygen saturation and intrauterine growth restriction using MRI studies. The magnetic resonance transverse relaxation time (T2) is inversely related to the concentration of deoxyhemoglobin so that high concentrations of deoxyhemoglobin produce a low signal intensity on T2-weighted MRI. In a normal fetus, the T2 signal is most likely to be the highest in which of the following vessels?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Ductus venosus

choices.text: Polycystic ovary syndrome

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because she has not had menstrual bleeding for the past 2 months. Menses had previously occurred at irregular 15-45 day intervals with moderate to heavy flow. Menarche was at the age of 14 years. Eight months ago, she was diagnosed with bipolar disorder and treatment with risperidone was begun. Her parents report that she is very conscious of her weight and appearance. She is 168 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 76 kg (168 1b); BMI is 26.9 kg/m2.

 

Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Serum hormone studies show:

 

 

A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Anovulatory cycles

choices.text: FUS- ETS fusion gene

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy comes with a fever and pain in his right upper limb. He has an expansile lesion in his right radius in the diaphysis. The histopathology of the lesion is shown below. What is the most accurate test among the following?
questions.solution: Ans. C) FUS- ETS fusion gene

questions.text: A 2 day old child is brought to the OPD. Mother complains that child is not feeding well and has bilious vomiting. The child is diagnosed with congenital megacolon and aganglionic segment of the colon is shown. Which of the following layers are affected in this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Layer 2 and 3

questions.text: A stillborn infant is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 32-year-old woman. The mother had no prenatal care. Examination of the stillborn shows a small pelvis, shallow intergluteal cleft, and club feet. An x-ray shows the absence of the sacrum and lumbar vertebrae. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Maternal diabetes mellitus

choices.text: Activation of ovarian luteinizing hormone receptors

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of infertility. She has been unable to conceive for the past 2 years. Menses occur at 45 to 80-day intervals. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 1b); BMI is 27.4 kg/m2. Physical examination shows facial acne and pigmented hair on the upper lip. Serum studies show elevated levels of testosterone and an LH:FSH ratio of 4:1. Treatment with the appropriate drug for this patient infertility is begun. Which of the following is the primary mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Inhibition of hypothalamic estrogen receptors

choices.text: All males will be affected and all females will be normal
Half of the males can be affected and half of the females can be carriers
All males will be affected and half of the females will be carriers
All of males and females will be affected

questions.text: A couple comes for prenatal genetic counselling. They have a family history of Hemophilia. They have a male child with Hemophilia and a normal female child. The mother's family has Hemophilia and the father's family is normal. What are the chances of their offspring being affected?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Half of the males can be affected and half of the females can be carriers

questions.text: A 29-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for evaluation of infertility. She has been unable to conceive for 14 months. One year ago, she stopped taking the oral contraceptive pill, which she had been taking since she was 17. Her husband's semen analysis was normal. Four years ago, she had an episode of a pelvic tenderness and vaginal discharge that resolved without treatment. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Before her marriage, she was sexually active with 3 male partners and used condoms inconsistently. She is 169 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 31.6 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's infertility?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of ciliary action

 

  • This woman has secondary infertility (previously fertile potential, now unable to conceive) with a normal menstrual cycle, indicating normal ovulation.
  • The history strongly suggests tubal factor infertility due to prior pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by sexually transmitted infections such as Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae. 
  • Although her infection resolved clinically, it likely caused subclinical tubal damage.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • PID leads to inflammation and scarring of the fallopian tubes. Chronic damage destroys tubal cilia, which are responsible for transporting the ovum toward the uterus.
  • Even if tubal patency remains (no complete blockage), loss of ciliary motility prevents fertilization by disrupting gamete transport. The end result is infertility despite normal ovulation and normal semen parameters.

 

Hence, the cause of infertility here is loss of ciliary action within the fallopian tubes secondary to postinfectious damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin resistance: Seen in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which causes anovulation and irregular menses. This patient has regular cycles, ruling out PCOS as the primary issue.

 

Option C. Ectopic endometrial tissue: Endometriosis can cause infertility but typically presents with pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, or dyspareunia, none of which are reported here. Moreover, her history of pelvic infection and sexual exposure pattern fits PID more closely.

 

Option D. Primary ovarian insufficiency: Presents with amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea and elevated FSH and LH levels. This patient has regular cycles, implying normal ovarian function.

choices.text: AFP low, Estriol Low, HCG high, Inhibin A high
AFP low, Estriol Low, HCG low, Inhibin A high
AFP low, Estriol Low, HCG low, Inhibin A low
AFP high, Estriol Low, HCG high, Inhibin A low

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes for a follow-up prenatal visit at 18 weeks' gestation. At 12 weeks' gestation, ultrasonography showed increased nuchal translucency and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PPAP-A) was decreased by 2 standard deviations.  Chronic villus sampling showed a 47, XX karyotype. During the visit, USG shows a hypoplastic nasal bone, shortened femur length, shortened middle phalanges of the fifth digits with clinodactyly. A quadruple marker test would most likely show which of the following sets of findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) AFP low, Estriol Low, HCG high, Inhibin A high

choices.text: Increased glomerular filtration barrier permeability
Increased glomerular filtration rate

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 16 weeks gestation comes to the office for a prenatal visit. She reports increased urinary frequency but otherwise feels well. Urinalysis shows mild glucosuria. Laboratory studies show a non-fasting serum glucose concentration of 100 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's glucosuria?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Increased glomerular filtration rate

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of oligomenorrhea and intermittent vaginal spotting for 5 months. She has also noted increased hair growth on her chin. She is not sexually active. Physical examination shows temporal hair recession and nodulocystic acne on her cheeks and forehead. Pelvic examination shows clitoral enlargement and a right adnexal mass. Laboratory studies show increased serum testosterone concentration; serum concentrations of androstenedione and dehydroepiandrosterone are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Ovarian thecoma

choices.text: Endometrial tissue within the myometrium on biopsy
Multiple bilateral ovarian cysts on ultrasonography
Reddish-black peritoneal lesions on laparoscopy
Concentric, solid myometrial tumors on MRI

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for infertility and dyspareunia workup. She also reports episodic back and pelvic pain over the past 6 months that lasts for 2-3 days; she has missed several days of work each month because of the pain. Menarche was at the age of 13 years, and menses occur at 26-28 day intervals. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing vulva and vagina. There is rectovaginal tenderness. Ultrasonography of the pelvis shows a retroverted normal-sized uterus. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Reddish-black peritoneal lesions on laparoscopy

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a physical examination prior to participating in sports. She is at the 50 percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows a normal female body habitus, a slight increase in breast areolar diameter with nipple protrusion, and normal-appearing external genitalia with sparse straight hair on the labia majora. The physician concludes that the patient's breast and external genitalia are in the same stage of sexual development. Which of the following terms best describes the sexual development of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Tanner stage 2

choices.text: Cooling of the face
Elevation of the lower extremities
Knee to chest positioning

questions.text: A previously healthy 2-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department because her lips turned blue while passing stools 30 minutes ago. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 65%, which increases to 76% on administration of 100% oxygen. Physical examination shows perioral cyanosis and retractions of the lower ribs with respiration. Cardiac examination shows a harsh grade 2/6 systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Knee to chest positioning

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with delayed developmental milestones presents to the OPD. A T2 weighted MRI is performed, and the imaging result is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Metachromatic leukodystrophy

choices.text: Penicillin plus toxoid
Single dose of immunoglobulin
Booster dose of toxoid

questions.text: An unvaccinated 5-year-old child presents with a sore throat and difficulty in swallowing. On examination, she has a greyish membrane over her tonsils. She has a fully vaccinated 2-year-old brother who was asymptomatic. What is the appropriate management of this contact?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Only Penicillin

choices.text: Synchronized cardioversion with 2J of current
Synchronized cardioversion with 1J of current

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the emergency department with lethargy, difficulty feeding, and dehydration. His vitals are stable and his ECG is shown below. What is the next step in his management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Adenosine 0.1mg/kg

questions.text: A previously healthy 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a 3-week history of recurrent vomiting and difficulty walking. Examination shows a broad-based gait and bilateral optic disc swelling. An MRI shows an intracranial tumor. A ventriculoperitoneal shunt is placed, and surgical excision of the tumor is Performed and her histopathological slide given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Medulloblastoma

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student who had a history of frequent respiratory infections as a child presents to the OPD. He has been experiencing recurrent episodes of coughing and shortness of breath over the past few months. He also complains of fatigue and chest pain, particularly on the left side. The CT scan reveals a mass in the lower lobe of his left lung as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Sequestration

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother for a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that occurred while attending a laser light show. His mother says that he has been otherwise healthy but "he often daydreams". Over the past several months, he has reported recurrent episodes of jerky movements of his fingers and arms. These episodes usually occurred shortly after waking up in the morning. He has not lost consciousness during these episodes. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Valproate

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because he has not yet begun to walk or speak. Assessment of his developmental milestones shows severe intellectual disability. He dies 6 months later from refractory seizures resulting in respiratory failure.  Autopsy shows pallor of the substantia nigra, locus ceruleus, and vagal nucleus dorsalis. The underlying  condition responsible for this patient's death is most likely caused by a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Phenylalanine hydroxylase

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother for a yearly physical examination. The patient feels well but is worried that she has not yet started puberty. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure is 152/91 mmHg, pulse is 75/min, and respirations are 18/ min. Physical examination is significant for a lack of secondary sexual characteristics; a blind vagina is noted on pelvic examination. Laboratory studies reveal hypokalemia and low testosterone and estradiol levels. Cytogenetic analysis shows a 46, XY karyotype. This patient most likely has deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution: Ans. C) 17 alpha-hydroxylase

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Papanicolaou stain?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Eosin B

questions.text: Identify the mode of inheritance from the pedigree chart given below:
questions.solution: Ans. D) XLD

questions.text: A 1-month-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of poor feeding, a hoarse cry, and lethargy for 1 week.  Physical examination shows scleral icterus, an enlarged tongue, and generalized hypotonia. The abdomen is distended and there is a reducible, soft protruding mass at the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Thyroid dysgenesis

choices.text: Vitamin D resistant rickets type 2
Vitamin D resistant rickets type 1

questions.text: A child with rickets not responding to treatment is being evaluated. Investigations show a serum calcium level of 9 mg/dL, phosphate level of 2 mg/dL, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and normal parathyroid hormone levels with normal arterial blood gas levels. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Hypophosphatemic rickets

questions.text: An infant of 2 months had a serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. The mother might have taken which of the following drugs during the third trimester for this to occur?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Co-trimoxazole

questions.text: A 28-year-old P2L2 woman presents with complaints of a mass descending through the vagina and wishes to retain her fertility. She underwent an abdominal sling procedure with mesh placement. Which is the correct site of attachment of the mesh?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Sacrum

choices.text: Primary oocyte with meiosis I completed
Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase of meiosis II
Primary oocyte arrested in prophase of meiosis I
Secondary oocyte with meiosis II completed

questions.text: After ovulation, in which phase is the released egg arrested?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase of meiosis II

questions.text: A previously healthy 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of fever, fatigue, and a sore throat for 8 days. She also has a diffuse rash that started yesterday. Three days ago, she took amoxicillin that she had at home. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse 99/min, blood pressure 106/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a morbilliform rash over her trunk and extremities. Oropharyngeal examination shows tonsillar enlargement and erythema with exudates. Tender cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy are present. Abdominal examination shows mild splenomegaly. A peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytosis with > 10% atypical lymphocytes. Which of the following is most likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Heterophile antibody test

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of nausea, increased urinary frequency, and breast tenderness. She has never had a menstrual period. She is actively involved in her school's volleyball team. She is 173 cm tall and weighs 54 kg; BMI is 18 kg/m2. Her breast and pubic hair development are at Tanner stage 5. Which of the following serum assays is the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Human chorionic gonadotropin

 

  • This patient has primary amenorrhea with fully developed secondary sexual characteristics (Tanner stage 5 breasts and pubic hair). 
  • She now presents with symptoms of early pregnancy — nausea, urinary frequency, and breast tenderness.

 

Key diagnostic clue:

 

  • A sexually active adolescent girl with amenorrhea and pregnancy symptoms → rule out pregnancy first, regardless of menstrual history.
  • Hence, the first and most appropriate test is serum or urine β-hCG to confirm or exclude pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estriol: Estriol is an estrogen measured to assess fetal well-being during pregnancy (e.g., in triple test). Not useful in evaluating amenorrhea or confirming pregnancy.

 

Option B. TSH: Thyroid dysfunction (especially hypothyroidism) can cause menstrual irregularities, but only after pregnancy is ruled out. It is a secondary test, not the first step.

 

Option D. Luteinizing hormone (LH): Measured to evaluate causes of primary amenorrhea like gonadal dysgenesis or hypothalamic dysfunction. However, this patient already shows full sexual maturation and pregnancy-like symptoms, so LH testing is premature until pregnancy is excluded.
